contextId.information: Adonijah probably sat at a table where he could watch all those he had invited as they ate and drank. The main idea is that the people Nathan named were with Adonijah and they were celebrating together. AT: "eating and drinking with him" or "eating and drinking where he can see them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Another possible meaning is "They began to act quickly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Another possible meaning is "Adonijah ... quickly went" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"do everything he promised he would do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

The idiom "with all ... heart" means "completely" and "with all ... soul" means "with all ... being." These two phrases have similar meanings. AT: "with all their being" or "with all their energy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: with all their heart and with all their soul

contextId.information: This is an idiom. "Shimei quickly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

To put an enemy under someone's foot means to conquer them. AT: "Yahweh was helping David to defeat his enemies" or "David was busy since Yahweh was giving him victory over his enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh was putting his enemies under the soles of his feet

contextId.information: This is an idiom that is used to introduce something that God told his prophets or his people. AT: "Yahweh spoke this message" or "Yahweh spoke these words" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

The idiom "with all ... heart" means "completely" and "with all ... soul" means "with all ... being." These two phrases have similar meanings. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:02:01|2:4]]. AT: "with all their being" or "with all their energy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: with all their heart and with all their soul

contextId.information: This is an idiom. AT: "she was utterly amazed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: there was no more breath in her

contextId.information: This is an idiom. AT: "who are always in your presence waiting to serve you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

The words "his heart had turned" refer to his having changed allegiance and affection. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:11:01|11:01]]. AT: "Solomon had stopped worshiping Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: his heart had turned away from him

contextId.information: To "stand before" is an idiom for serving the king in his presence. AT: "the old men who counseled Solomon" or "the old men who attended to Solomon" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: the old men who had stood before Solomon

contextId.information: This is an idiom and can be stated in active form. AT: "Yahweh caused things to happen like this" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: it was a turn of events brought about by Yahweh

contextId.information: This is an idiom that is used to introduce something that God told his prophets or his people. AT: "God spoke this message ... and he said" or "God spoke these words ... and he said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: the word of God came ... it said

contextId.information: "Went up" is an idiom for going to a sacred place to worship since these altars were located on high places. AT: "offered sacrifices on the altar" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means he prophesied toward the altar in a loud and condemning voice. AT: "prophesied loudly toward the altar" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This is an idiom that means Yahweh spoke. Here "word" represents Yahweh's message. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:06:11|6:11]]. AT: "by the message of Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

This is an idiom that means Yahweh spoke. Here "word" represents Yahweh's message. Translate this phrase as in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:13:14|13:17]]. AT: "by the message of Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is an idiom that means marched against or attacked. AT: "came to attack" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom. Here the word "Look" adds emphasis to what follows and validates what was just said. AT: "As proof that I want a treaty with you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This idiom means God spoke. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:06:11|6:11]]. AT: "Yahweh spoke his message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This is an idiom that is used to introduce something that God told his prophets or his people. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:06:11|6:11]]. AT: "Yahweh spoke this message" or "Yahweh spoke these words" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Speaking "by" a prophet represents telling a prophet to speak and the prophet speaking. AT: "that Yahweh told Jehu the prophet to speak against Baasha" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: which he spoke against Baasha by Jehu the prophet

contextId.information: This is an idiom that means "to serve." AT: "whom I serve" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This idiom means God spoke. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:06:11|6:11]]. AT: "Yahweh spoke his message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This idiom means God spoke. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:06:11|6:11]]. AT: "Yahweh spoke his message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom that means Yahweh causes it to rain. AT: "Yahweh causes rain to fall" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom. AT: "lay on top of the child" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
To "stand before" is an idiom for being in someone's presence and ready to serve him. AT: "whom I serve" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This idiom means Yahweh spoke and "word" is a metonymy representing the message. "Yahweh spoke his word and said to him." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:06:11|6:11]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the word of Yahweh came to him and said to him

contextId.information: "Before me" is an idiom for standing in front of someone. AT: "on the mountain in my presence" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom to express agreement. AT: "I agree with you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This idiom emphasizes what they will say. AT: "Listen" or "Pay attention to what we are about to tell you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"Heat of the battle" is an idiom to express the most intense and fierce fighting. AT: "to where the battle was most intense" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: into the heat of the battle

contextId.information: This idiom means that Yahweh spoke or has sent a message. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:06:11|6:11]]. AT: "Yahweh spoke this message" or "Yahweh spoke" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This idiom means that Yahweh spoke or has sent a message. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:06:11|6:11]]. AT: "Yahweh spoke this message" or "Yahweh spoke"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

Jehoshaphat tells Ahab that he, his people, and his horses belong to Ahab, meaning that Ahab can command them as he pleases. AT: "I, my soldiers, and my horses are yours to use in any way you want" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: I am like you, my people are like your people, and my horses are like your horses
